title: Pain When Coughing
description: Pain when coughing means you feel discomfort or pain in your chest, side, ribs, back, or throat every time you cough. It can be mild or sharp, depending on the cause.

sections.heading: Possible Causes
sections.content:
Common cold or flu – Sore throat, muscle strain, or inflamed airways.

Chest infection (bronchitis or pneumonia) – Deep chest pain, often with mucus or fever.

Muscle strain – Coughing a lot can strain chest or rib muscles.

Rib injury or fracture – A cracked or bruised rib can hurt when you cough or breathe.

Pleurisy – Inflammation of the lung lining causing sharp chest pain.

Acid reflux (GERD) – Stomach acid can irritate the throat and chest.

Asthma – Tightness in chest, wheezing, and cough.

Lung problems – Like a collapsed lung or a blood clot (rare, but serious).

COVID-19 – Can cause cough with chest pain and breathing difficulty.

sections.heading: Symptoms to Watch For
sections.content:
Sharp or stabbing pain when coughing

Pain that spreads to shoulder or back

Shortness of breath

Fever or chills

Yellow or bloody mucus

Chest tightness

Fatigue or weakness

Wheezing

sections.heading: When to Go to the Doctor or ER
sections.content:
Chest pain is sudden or severe

Trouble breathing or speaking

High fever (above 101°F or 38.3°C)

Coughing up blood

Fast heartbeat or dizziness

Chest pain after injury (possible rib fracture)

If pain lasts more than a few days

sections.heading: Home Care and First Aid
sections.content:
Rest your body and avoid overexerting your lungs.

Drink warm fluids to soothe your throat and loosen mucus.

Use a humidifier to moisten the air and reduce coughing.

Warm compress on your chest or back for muscle pain.

Cough medicine (if needed): Use over-the-counter remedies like cough suppressants or lozenges.

Pain relievers: Take paracetamol or ibuprofen for pain and inflammation (ask a doctor if unsure).

sections.heading: Precautions
sections.content:
Avoid smoking or secondhand smoke.

Don’t lie flat while coughing — use pillows to keep your upper body raised.

Avoid spicy and acidic foods if you have acid reflux.

Avoid cold air — wear a scarf or mask in cold weather.

Don’t ignore persistent or worsening symptoms.

sections.heading: Emergency Medicines (only under doctor advice)
sections.content:
Antibiotics: If there’s a bacterial infection (not for viral colds).

Bronchodilators or inhalers: For asthma or wheezing.

Cough syrups: For dry or wet cough (consult doctor for type).

Steroids: For inflammation or severe asthma (prescribed only).

sections.heading: What Not to Do
sections.content:
Don’t take antibiotics without a prescription.

Don’t suppress a wet cough too much (coughing helps clear mucus).

Don’t smoke or vape.

Don’t delay seeing a doctor if pain is strong or new.
